712547f-a.text:
117, 119, 121 East 39th Street, north side, between Park and
Lexington Avenues.
1921.
gift of E. M. Jenks.

712548f-a.text:
115, 117, 11V East 39th Street, north side, between Park and
Lexington Avenues.
March, 1913.
Brown Brothers.

712550f-a.text:
East 39th Street, west from Park Avenue. At the left and right respectively are an open lot and the Princeton Club. At Madison Avenue is another clearance. View 2 is closer to same. This emphasizes the reconstructed former residence housing the administrative staff of the Henry Street Nursing Service. It stands at the S.E. corner of Madison Avenue. Mrs. Goadby Loew, the daughter
of George F. Baker, resided here.
April 11, 1940
No's. 1-2
P. L. Sperr

East 39th Street, west from Park Avenue. At the left and right respectively are an open lot and the Princeton Club. At Madison Avenue is another clearance. View 2 is closer to same. 712551f-a.text:
30th Street, north side, west from but not including Park Avenue.
December 2, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

712552f-a.text:
33 East 39th Street, north side, between Park and Madison Avenues, at the time of its purchase by a family returning to Murray Hill.
1Vlu.

712553f.text:
30, 28, 26 East 39th Street, south side, between Park and Madison Avenues. No. 28 is the Psi Upsilon Club of New York.
About 1920.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.
Neg. #1951

712556f-a.text:
(1)
39th Street, north side, from Park to Madison Avenues, a view of the roofs and of the skyscrapers in the background, and not showing the Park Avenue corner.
December 2, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, a view of the fronts of the houses, four years later showing the Princeton Club at the corner of Park Avenue but not showing the Madison Avenue corner.
March 27, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

712557f-a.text:
3Vth Street, noth side, from Park to Fifth Avenues, showing the tower of 9 East 39th Street or 10 East 40th. Street.
October 1, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

712616f-a.text:
119 East 40th Street, north side, between Park and Lexington
Avenues.
1914.

712619f-a.text:
Murray Hill Hotel, 40th Street side, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of Park Avenue.
August 1, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

712620f-a.text:
40th Street, south sioe, from Park to Madison Avenues. The corner
house, 78 Park Avenue, is being demolished.
Ootober 2, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

722085f-a.text:
Park Ave., north from East 39th Street, showing W.P.A. employees reconstructing the former street car (before that,used by railroad) tunnel for future vehicular use. Shown in the background is the automobile ramp around Grand Central station that this will hook up to.
1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

722086f-a.text:
77 Park Avenue at the S.E. corner of 39th Street, a new apartment house nearing completion. This entire block has been rebuilt since 1921; the building partly shown on the right is the corner house at 38th Street which replaced the old C. D. Barney house in 1922. Compare this picture with the N.E. corner of 38th Street in early 1922 and notice also how the center parks have been modernized
to leave more room for motor traffic.
1924.
Joseph Smith.
Neg # 1019

722087f-a.text:
Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, Manhattan
Federal Art Project
"Changing New York'
Berenice Abbott, photographer
Neg. No. 172
[Note: negative is at Museum of the City of New York]
Code ID
Oct. 8, 1936

722091f-a.text:
Park Avenue at S.W. corner of 39th Street, showing old mansion and two houses acjacent on Park Avenue which will be demolished in 1933. The top of the Allerton House Fraternity Clubs building at Madison Avenue and 38th Street is iust visible
over the roof of the corner house.
May 31, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, five years later, showing demolition nearly complete. The large blank wall shown in the center of the picture is that of the first house on the south side of 39th Street. In the background rise the towers of the Allerton House Fraternity Clubs, on the S.E. corner of 38th Street, the International Combustion Building at 200 Madison Avenue, and,
between them, the Empire State Builoing.
September 9, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

Park Avenue at S.W. corner of 39th Street, showing old mansion and two houses acjacent on Park Avenue which will be demolished in 1933. The top of the Allerton House Fraternity Clubs building at Madison Avenue and 38th Street is iust visible

722093f-a.text:
(1)
90-92 Park Avenue, west side, between 39th and 40th Streets: two old houses which are to be demolished in October 1931.
December 13, 1930.
P..L. Sperr, Photographer.
(2)
The adjoining houses Nos. 94, 96 and 98 Park Ave., at, adjoining,
and south of the S.W. corner of East 40th Street.
December 13, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

722093f-b.text:
(1)
90-92 Park Avenue, west side, between 39th and 40th Streets: two old houses which are to be demolished in October 1931.
December 13, 1930.

(2)
The adjoining houses Nos. 94, 96 and 98 Park Ave., at, adjoining,
and south of the S.W. corner of East 40th Street.

722094f-a.text:
(1)
Park Ave., east side, north from East 39th to 40th Streets. Show: at the N.E. corner is a country home, erected for demonstration purposes. Buildings standing at the S.E. corner of 40th Street, are Nos. 93-99 inclusive. No. 99-97 (at and adjoining the corner), is the Nurses Club;
Nos. 95-93, the Navy Club.
March 22, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A closer view of "America's Little House'.
March 22, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
This entire block front has been purchased by the City as a new site of t1e Appellate Division of the Supreme Court. On completion of same they will move from their present quarters at the N.E. corner of Madison Ave. and East 25th Street. The Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service have purchased the former Wm. Goadhhy Loew residence at the S.W. corner of Madison Ave. and East 39th Street and will shortly move their executive offices there after remodelling.strdctcrecto meet their needs. For a fuller account see the New York Sun of February 15, 1936 and March
29, 1938 and the New York Times of March 25, 1938.

(1)

722095f-a.text:
(1)
Fark Avenue, east side, from 39th to 40th Streets, seen from t) tall building at 271 Madison Avenuc, showing the Nunses' Clut at the N.E. corner of 40th Street and the Navy Club adjoining it. The other houses in the block, beginning with the small one in the middle, are to be demolished in 1933. In the background may be seen some of the 42nd Street skyscrape the twin buildings of Tudor City overlooking the East River, the dim outlines of Long Island City on the other side.
December 2, 1931.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.
(2)
The same, at an earlier date.
October 12, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
N-~ 292G

(1)
Fark Avenue, east side, from 39th to 40th Streets, seen from t) tall building at 271 Madison Avenuc, showing the Nunses' Clut at the N.E. corner of 40th Street and the Navy Club adjoining it. 722096f-a.text:
Park Avenue, east side, from 39th to 42nd Streets, showing demolition of houses from the N.E. corner of 39th Street to and including the little one in the middle of the block. On the site thus vacant the Little House will be erected late in 1934. On the N.E. corner of 40th Street stands the Architects' Building (1916), and above it the smaller and older 103 Park Avenue. The Pershing Square Building follows in the block from 41st to 42nd Streets, where the Grand Union Hotel stood prior to 1915.
In the background the Chanin Building partly hides the tower of the Chrysler Building.
September 10, 1933.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

722097f-a.text:
Park Avenue, north on west side, from 39th to 42nd Streets, showing the Princeton Club at the N.W. corner of 39th Street and the three buildings in the northern half of that block which are about to be demolished. The Hotel Belmont, in the block from 41st to 42nd Streets, above the Murray Hill Hotel, has just been demolished.
In the background are shown the Lefcourt Colonial Building at Madison Avenue and 41st Street, and the Lincoln Building at 60 East 42nd Street.
August 25, 1931.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

722102f-a.text:
(1)
Park Avenue, east side, from 39th to 40th Streets, seen from 40th Street across the lot left by demolition of buildings on the S.W. corner of 40th Street. The house shown on he S.E. corner of 40th Street is the Visiting Nurses' Club, and the adjoining house the Navy Club. The rest of the buildings
in the block will be demolished in 1933.
December 3, 1931.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.
(2)
The same, but seen across the Avenue from 39th Street, and showing demolition of the olc bnownstone houses, leaving
only the two in the northern end of the block.
September 10, 1933.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

722102f-b.text:
(1)
Park Avenue, east side, from 39th to 40th Streets, seen from 40th Street across the lot left by demolition of buildings on the S.W. corner of 40th Street. The house shown on he S.E. corner of 40th Street is the Visiting Nurses' Club, and the adjoining house the Navy Club. The rest of the buildings
in the block will be demolished in 1933.
December 3, 1931.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.
(2)
The same, but seen across the Avenue from 39th Street, and showing demolition of the olc bnownstone houses, leaving
only the two in the northern end of the block.
September 10, 1933.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

722103f-a.text:
Park Avenue, west side, from 40th to 39th Streets, showing Murray Hill Hotel on the N.W. corner of 40th Street; the view is from the Pershing Square Building on the east side at 41st Street.
The old houses which are being demolished on the S.W. corner of 40th Street will be replaced in 1933 by a white two-story structure with stores. The buildings on the S.W. corner of 39th Street will be demolished in September, 1933.
The elevation of the camera gives an especially good view of the Empire State Building at Fifth Avenue and 34th Street, the tallest building in the world.
October 21, 1931.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

722104f-a.text:
Park Avenue, weat side, at 40th Street, showing the old Murray Hill Hotel, from 40th to 41st Streets, and the houses on the S.W. corner of 40th Street which will be demolished in 1931.
February 6, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

722105f-a.text:
Park Avenue, north from 40th Street, showing the Grand Central Station as rebuilt during the years around 1910, the Pershing Square Viaduct conducting motor vehicles from 40th to 46th Streets, and the demolition of the Hotel Belmont on the west side of the Avenue from 41st to 42nd Streets. The New York Central Building (1928) at 46th Street is seen over the roof of the Station. Underneath the station clock, in front of the large window and fading south on the Viaduct, may be seen the statue of Commodore Vanderbilt, who built up the New York Central Railroad system.
June 14, 1931.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

722107f-a.text:
Park Avenue, east aide at 40th Street, showing the Nurses' Club at the S.E. corner of 40th Street and the National Navy Club
next to it.
On the N.E. corner may be seen the Architects' Building, 101 Park Avenue, built 19lo, and the smaller and rather older Terminal
Building, No. 103.
Notice the traffic signal torer characteristic of the mid 1920's.
October 12, 1927.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

722108f-a.text:
Rark Avenue, east side at 40th Street, seen from a considerable height. On the N.E. corner stands the Architects' Building. 101 Park Avenue, built about 1916. Cn the S.E. co ne may be seen the Nursos' Club, and next to it the National Navy Club. The other buildings facing Park Avenue in that block, beginning with the small 3-story house to the right of the Navy Club, will
be demolished in 1931.
The skyscraper in the right background is the Chanin Building.
December 2, 1931.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

722108f-b.text:
Rark Avenue, east side at 40th Street, seen from a considerable height. On the N.E. corner stands the Architects' Building. 101 Park Avenue, built about 1916. Cn the S.E. co ne may be seen the Nursos' Club, and next to it the National Navy Club. The other buildings facing Park Avenue in that block, beginning with the small 3-story house to the right of the Navy Club, will
be demolished in 1931.
The skyscraper in the right background is the Chanin Building.
December 2, 1931.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

722109f.text:
Park Avenue, west side, from 4'th to 41st Streets, showing
the Murray Hill Hotel.
Sift of E. M. Jenks  1913

722110f-a.text:
Park Avenue, west side, from 40th to 41st Streets, showing the old Murray Hill Botel, which dates back to the 1870's, against a background of modern skyscrapers. To the right is the Lincoln Building, completed late in 1929, at 60 East 42nd Street, and to the left the Lefcourt Colonial Building (1929) on the S.W. corner of Madison Avenue and 41st Street and the Murray Hill Offices building (1926), which together take up the entire east side of Madison Avenue from 41st to 40th Streets. Behind the latter, to the left of the Lefcourt tower, may be seen the top of 500 Fifth Avenue, completed on the N.W. corner of 42nd Street in January 1931.
December 2, 1931.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.
(2)
The ssme, but showing a little of the cleaing at the S.W. corner of 40th Street, and missing the tops of the Lincoln
and Lefcourt Colonial buildings.
In the block above the Muray Hill, from 4lst to 42nd Streets, the Hotel Belmont has been den:olished. Through the gap thus created may be seen the west side of Vanderbilt Avenue st 43rd Street; the Hotel Biltmore (erected about 1914) is the
building shown in part on the N.W. corner.
December 2, 1931
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

722111f.text:
Murray Hill Hotel, Park Avenue, west side, from 40th to 41st Streets, showing part of the 41st Street side of the Hotel Belmont, the latter hotel, although uch newer, will be demolished in 1931.
In the foreground may be seen the southern end of the Pershing Square viaduct. Behind the Murray Hill Hotel, on the right, may be seen a large office building under construction at the N.E. corner of Madison Avenue and 41st Street. Compare this with the picture taken in 1918.
June 1925.
Brown Brothers, Photographers.

722112f-a.text:
Murray Hill Hotel: Spiral
From Park Avenue and 40th Street, Manhattan
Yederal Art Project
"Changing New York'
Berenice Abbott, photographer
Neg. No. 37
[Note: negative at Museum of the City ofNew York]

y13EShWSSOD5B2EE

722114f-a.text:
(1)
Park Avenue, west side, from 40th to 42nd Streets, including two buildings on the S.W. corner of 40th Street which will be demolished in October 1931. The old Murray Hill Hotel is shown in the block from 40th to 41st Streets and the Hotel Belmont (1906-1931) in the block above it, as they appeared before the Lincoln Building was erected alongside
the Belmont at 60 East 42nd Street.
At 4Oth Street may be seen a traffic signal tower of the type
in use from about 1925 to 1928.
February 6, 1928.
P. L. Sper, Photographer.
(2)
The same, but a closer view not showing the S.W. corner of 40th Street, taken after the erection of the Lincoln Building and before the demolition of the Hotel Belmont (1906-31).
December 13, 1930.
L. Sperr, Photographer.
(3)
The same, showing the clearing on the S.W. corner of 40th Street, and the view of the Hotel Biltmore, on Vanderbilt Avenue from 43rd to 44th Steets, mmade possible by the demolition of the Hotel Belmont in the block north of the Murray Hill Hotel.
DDecember 2, 1931.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

(1)

722118f-a.text:
Park Avenue, west side, from 41st to 40th Streets, showing the old Murray Hill Hotel and part of the excavation, at the N.W. corner of 41st Street, left by demolition of the Hotel Belmont. In the immediate foreground southbound automobiles on the Pershing Square Viaduct are shown waiting for the green light.
October 21, 1931.
L. Sperr, Photographer.

722194f-a.text:
(1)
Park Avenue, east side, from 42nd to 39th Streets, showing the Pershing Square Viaduct and the Pershing Square Building, built about 1923 in the block from 42nd to 41st Streets where the Grand Union Hotel used to stand. In the right foreground, opposite this building, the Hotel Belmont (opened 1906) is in the final stages of demolition.
103 Park Avenue, on the S.E. corner of 41st Street, was built about 1900, and 101 Park Avenue, on the N.E. corner of 40th Street, in 1916.
August 25, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, showing less of the Pershing Square Building and more of the demolition of the Belmont on the west side of the Avenue.
The tower in the background, incidentally, is the colored tower of the new Town House apartment building at 106 East 38th Street.
August 25, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The Pershing Square Building only.
August 25, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Park Avenue, east side, from 42nd to 39th Streets, showing the Pershing Square Viaduct and the Pershing Square Building, built about 1923 in the block from 42nd to 41st Streets where the Grand Union Hotel used to stand. In the right foreground, opposite this building, the Hotel Belmont (opened 1906) is in the final stages of demolition.
